June 17, 1990: Fiction
THE BURDEN OF PROOF, by Scott Turow.  (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.95.) An
attorney  tries to unravel the mystery of his wife's death  while defending his
wheeler-dealer brother-in-law.
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss.  (Random House, $12.95.) The
problems of finding  your way through life; in verse and pictures.
SEPTEMBER, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dunne/St.  Martin's, $22.95.) Guests from
many parts of the  world encounter their often unexpected destinies  during a get-
together in a small Scottish town.
THE STAND, by Stephen King. (Doubleday,  $24.95.) Doomsday brings horrors to
America; the  uncut version of a novel first published in 1978.
DRAGON, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster,  $21.95.) In 1993, Dirk Pitt moves
fast to save  America from a Japanese extremist.
AN INCONVENIENT WOMAN, by Dominick  Dunne. (Crown, $19.95.) Manners,
morals and  murder in Los Angeles's high society.
THE GOLDEN ORANGE, by Joseph Wambaugh.  (Perigord/Morrow, $19.95.)
Murder and chicanery  amid Orange County's yachts and mansions.
THE BOURNE ULTIMATUM, by Robert Ludlum.  (Random House, $21.95.) Jason
Bourne plans to  infiltrate the ruthless Medusa Brigade.
FAMILY PICTURES, by Sue Miller. (Harper &  Row, $19.95.) The good and bad
times of a large  Chicago clan during the past 40 years.
SKINNY LEGS AND ALL, by Tom Robbins.  (Bantam, $19.95.) The horror and
humor of the  upcoming apocalypse are played out at a  restaurant near the
United Nations.
THE GOLD COAST, by Nelson DeMille. (Warner,  $19.95.) How life changes for
an old WASP family  when the head of a crime family becomes its  neighbor on
Long Island's North Shore.
THE OUTLAWS OF MESQUITE, by Louis  L'Amour. (Bantam, $16.95.) Eight short
stories  about the American frontier.
''G'' IS FOR GUMSHOE, by Sue Grafton. (Holt,  $16.95.) On her 33d birthday, the
private eye Kinsey  Millhone finds herself on a killer's hit list.
CLEAR AND PRESENT DANGER, by Tom  Clancy. (Putnam, $21.95.) The
C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan  fights Colombian drug lords.
THE MUSIC ROOM, by Dennis McFarland.  (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) After his
Non-Fiction
MEN AT WORK, by George F. Will. (Macmillan,  $19.95.) The political pundit and
baseball buff  describes the craft of the game.
DAVE BARRY TURNS 40, by Dave Barry. (Crown,  $16.95.) Reflections on the
crises of middle age by  the syndicated humorist.
DON'T SHOOT, IT'S ONLY ME, by Bob Hope with  Melville Shavelson. (Putnam,
$19.95.) The  comedian reminisces about his career.
BARBARIANS AT THE GATE, by Bryan  Burrough and John Helyar. (Harper &
Row,  $22.95.) The 1988 battle for control of RJR Nabisco.
MEGATRENDS 2000, by John Naisbitt and  Patricia Aburdene. (Morrow, $21.95.)
Prognostications for the next decade.
ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN  KINDERGARTEN, by Robert
Fulghum. (Villard,  $17.95.) Inspirational essays.
IT WAS ON FIRE WHEN I LAY DOWN ON IT, by  Robert Fulghum. (Villard,
$17.95.) A new collection  of inspirational essays.
IN THE ARENA, by Richard Nixon. (Simon &  Schuster, $21.95.) The 37th
President reflects on his  public career and private life.
LIAR'S POKER, by Michael Lewis. (Norton,  $19.95.) Wall Street's tumultuous
LEGACIES, by Bette Bao Lord. (Knopf, $19.95.)  Reflections on the Chinese
experience during the  past quarter-century.
MY LIFE IN THREE ACTS, by Helen Hayes with  Katherine Hatch. (Wolff/Harcourt
Brace  Jovanovich, $19.95.) The actress's memoirs.
THE SEARCH FOR MODERN CHINA, by  Jonathan D. Spence. (Norton, $29.95.)
Four  centuries of Chinese history.
HEAD FIRST, by Norman Cousins. (Dutton,  $19.95.) How the brain affects the
body's endocrine  and immune systems.
FATHER SON & CO., by Thomas J. Watson Jr. and  Peter Petre. (Bantam,
$22.95.) The autobiography  of the man who succeeded his father as head of
I.B.M.
PARTING WITH ILLUSIONS, by Vladimir  Pozner. (Atlantic Monthly, $19.95.) The
autobiography of a man, raised in New York, who  became a commentator on
Radio Moscow.
